headline: 'Do You Know Me? Do You Know My Heart?'
content:
Advertisement

      By LIZ ROBBINS

DEC. 10, 2015

After Donald J. Trump called for Muslims to be barred from entering the United States, The New York Times asked Muslims in New York for their reactions. Here are excerpts from those interviews, in which they shared their personal experiences as Muslims, New Yorkers and Americans.
On a possible Trump presidency: “I told my wife if Trump gets elected, I’ll leave this country.“I have three daughters. When we first came to America [in 2002], I had a sister and we used to live in Nashville, Tenn. It was a small town. She wore a head scarf. She was the only one in middle school who wore a head scarf. At that point in time, some person makes a remark that, ‘Oh, she’s a cousin of Osama bin Laden.’ The teacher took the matter into her hands and calmed down the situation.“Now, if someone does that similar thing to my daughters, and the teachers are not able to – if they are a Trump fan – and there is no one to rectify that wrong behavior, that’s what I’m afraid of. “How can you normalize the situation? If the president is like that, he has the support.” Liz RobbinsOn growing up Muslim: “Right before fourth grade, I remember when I was playing on the playground and some tall kids came and pushed me. I used to wear my hijab back then. There was some hurtful things thrown at me. When I came home and cried, I remember my parents telling me, I should not be ashamed of who I am, and nobody is going to push me around. “People sometimes, when you’re standing on the street, on the ferry or in the train, people keep staring at you. Especially after what happened in Paris, after what Donald Trump said, about us wearing a badge and trying to prove us being Muslims and having actually identification as a Muslim. “That was something that kind of felt disrespectful. I don’t see anyone else doing that. I feel like it’s something once that Hitler said to the Jews that they should start wearing a badge as identification. Why do I have to tell who I am? I was born and raised in America. I feel like that’s the only identification I should have on me.” Liz RobbinsOn being Muslim in New York: “When I’m on the train, people don’t want to sit beside me. I’d like to talk but it’s easier to be silent. It’s sad. It’s easier for those who look American, but people who dress like me with a beard and kufi and my wife, who is covered, guys on the train see you and give you a grilled look.“Do you know me? Do you know my heart? Why are you judging by looking at me?”Emily PalmerOn his reaction to the San Bernardino attack: “The first reaction, obviously, was shock. As officers, we had the radios tuned in because we wanted to find out what was happening, right after the shooting. We tweeted about the S.U.V. and a safety hot line. “When we found out that the shooters were Muslim – because we didn’t know that at first – it was very disturbing. It’s hard because we work so hard against that stereotype and when people hear that they were Muslim, it takes you back. We have to work harder to say that’s not us. “Right after the 9/11 attacks, I was in the military, and each soldier was assigned to a police officer to help protect the World Trade Center. This was the day after the attacks. “We were talking, and he said, “Killing is in their religion,’ and I let him talk. Then I said, “What do you think I am?” I said, ‘I’m Muslim,’ and his jaw dropped and his eyes widened and he said, ‘I’m sorry.’ I said, ‘Don’t be sorry. It’s not your fault because whatever you hear, you believe.’” Emily PalmerOn teaching and wearing the hijab: “When my students get up to say the Pledge of Allegiance, I’m up there with them, pledging every single day. It’s devastating to think people are questioning our loyalty to a country that we love. “I work in a very diverse school, so many of my students interact with Muslim students all day. I’ll be honest, they never have asked me, ‘Why do you wear the hijab?’ A lot of them are just like, ‘Oh they practice the Muslim faith. They wear it because of modesty.’“I think I’m the only hijabi teacher in New Utrecht High School, and you know, some of them have asked me questions about my faith, but nothing I deemed inappropriate or made me feel uncomfortable.” Elizabeth A. HarrisOn being Muslim in Harlem: “One thing about being a Muslim in Harlem in the 70s, it was not that weird. Why? Because the Nation of Islam, Elijah Muhammad, Malcolm X – it was the Harlem base here a few blocks away. In terms of African-Americans being Muslim, it was not unusual. “Muslims had a very positive image. People respected us. Our mosque, we used to have an annual street fair, pre-Ramadan and post-Ramadan. There are neighborhood kids, they’re not Muslim, who have the memory that the mosque had the street fair, we had the vendors, we had the music, we had the face-painting and all the activities for the kids. “To me, now, it’s the same in Harlem. Why? We have so much diversity in Harlem that we’re accustomed to the diversity and Muslims are so ever-present that everybody knows a Muslim. And so, to hear somebody’s rhetoric over the media, it’s like, I know Muslims, hey, it’s not a problem for me. “And if it’s with people of African descent, we’re rather accustomed, certainly of my generation, to discrimination. So what else is new? Who is the new ‘other’ this week?” Liz RobbinsOn being Muslim and a police chaplain: “One of the things that we do as police chaplains is we go down to the ground zero memorial every year on Sept. 11. We have breakfast with family members who lost loved ones on that day. Before the current structure that’s there, and while it was being built, the ceremony was a little more closed off. On the ninth anniversary of the attack, Vice President Biden was there. We were in a place where they had the stage where the ceremony was taking place, in front of that was an area for family members and city officials.“I’m wearing my police uniform, which is an inspector’s uniform, and I’m standing and I’m talking to family members prior to the ceremony starting, and three men approach me who are wearing suits, saying, ‘Secret Service has identified you from the top of a building and they want us to check your credentials just in case.’ I said, ‘Just in case what?’ And they said, ‘We’re sorry that we’re doing this to you,’ and I said, ‘Then why are you doing it?’ What’s being questioned there is not really my physical presence, but I think a lot of the validity of my emotion tied to that space.” J. David GoodmanOn dealing with the public: “I’m a station agent. I’m a frontline employee and I deal with customers every day. From time to time you face customers that are a little rude. You can’t always accommodate every need like a MetroCard malfunction. For some, when you can’t help them, it’s not uncommon to hear ‘Muslim, go back to your country.’ We get that all the time. It’s a normal thing now these days to hear. ‘You don’t belong here. Why don’t you go back?’”Jeffrey E. SingerAdvertisement
